name.text: Truth Tables and Logical Connectives: Interchanging Operators and Analyzing Patterns

questiontext.text:
Logical connectives can be used together to create more complex statements.

Let \(p\) and \(q\) be statements.

1. (a) Complete the truth tables of \( (\neg p \vee q) \wedge q\) and that of \( (\neg p \wedge q) \vee q\)

p q \( \neg p \) \(\neg p \vee q\)

 \( (\neg p \vee q) \wedge q\) \( \neg p \wedge q\) \( (\neg p \wedge q) \vee q\)
True True
 [[input:ans1ss]] [[input:ans1s]] [[input:ans1]] [[input:ans2s]] [[input:ans2]] [[feedback:prt1]]
True
 False [[input:ans3ss]] [[input:ans3s]] [[input:ans3]] [[input:ans4s]] [[input:ans4]] [[feedback:prt2]]
False
 True
 [[input:ans5ss]] [[input:ans5s]] [[input:ans5]] [[input:ans6s]] [[input:ans6]] [[feedback:prt3]]
False
 False [[input:ans7ss]] [[input:ans7s]] [[input:ans7]] [[input:ans8s]] [[input:ans8]] [[feedback:prt4]]

(b) What do you notice about the truth tables of \( (\neg p \vee q) \wedge q\) and that of \( (\neg p \wedge q) \vee q\)? [[input:ans9]] [[feedback:prt5]] [[validation:ans9]]

Based on this result, a creative student concludes that you can always interchange \( \vee \) and \( \wedge \) without changing the truth table.

Is the student right? [[input:ans10]] [[validation:ans10]] [[feedback:prt6]]

[[validation:ans1s]] [[validation:ans1]] [[validation:ans2]][[validation:ans3s]] [[validation:ans3]] [[validation:ans4]][[validation:ans5s]] [[validation:ans5]] [[validation:ans6]] [[validation:ans7s]][[validation:ans7]][[validation:ans8]] [[validation:ans1ss]] [[validation:ans2s]] [[validation:ans3ss]] [[validation:ans4s]] [[validation:ans5ss]] [[validation:ans6s]] [[validation:ans7ss]] [[validation:ans8s]]

2. (a) Complete the truth tables of \( (\neg p \vee q) \wedge p\) and that of \( (\neg p \wedge q) \vee p\)

p q \( \neg p \) \(\neg p \vee q\) \( (\neg p \vee q) \wedge p\)  \( \neg p \wedge q \) \( (\neg p \wedge q) \vee p\)
True True
 [[input:ans11ss]] [[input:ans11s]] [[input:ans11]] [[input:ans12s]] [[input:ans12]] [[feedback:prt7]]
True
 False [[input:ans13ss]] [[input:ans13s]] [[input:ans13]] [[input:ans14s]] [[input:ans14]] [[feedback:prt8]]
False
 True
 [[input:ans15ss]] [[input:ans15s]] [[input:ans15]] [[input:ans16s]] [[input:ans16]] [[feedback:prt9]]
False
 False
 [[input:ans17ss]] [[input:ans17s]] [[input:ans17]] [[input:ans18s]] [[input:ans18]] [[feedback:prt10]]

(b) What do you notice about the truth tables of \( (\neg p \vee q) \wedge p\) and that of \( (\neg p \wedge q) \vee p\)? [[input:ans19]] [[feedback:prt11]] [[validation:ans19]]

(c) What do you think of the rule formulated in 1.(a) by the student? [[input:ans20]] [[feedback:prt12]]

[[validation:ans20]] [[validation:ans11]] [[validation:ans12]] [[validation:ans13]] [[validation:ans14]][[validation:ans15]] [[validation:ans16]] [[validation:ans17]] [[validation:ans18]] [[validation:ans11ss]] [[validation:ans11s]] [[validation:ans12s]][[validation:ans13ss]] [[validation:ans13s]] [[validation:ans14s]] [[validation:ans15ss]] [[validation:ans15s]][[validation:ans16s]] [[validation:ans17ss]] [[validation:ans17s]] [[validation:ans18s]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

1. a Complete the truth tables of \( (\neg p \vee q) \wedge q\) and that of \( (\neg p \wedge q) \vee q\)

p q \( \neg p \) \(\neg p \vee q\)

 \( (\neg p \vee q) \wedge q\) \( \neg p \wedge q\) \( (\neg p \wedge q) \vee q\)
True True
 {@taf@} {@tat@} {@tat@} {@taf@} {@tat@}
True
 False {@taf@} {@taf@} {@taf@} {@taf@} {@taf@}
False
 True
 {@tat@} {@tat@} {@tat@} {@tat@} {@tat@}
False
 False {@tat@} {@tat@} {@taf@} {@taf@} {@taf@}

1.(b). We notice that the tables are the same. So the student is right by making such claiming.

2. (a) Complete the truth tables of \( (\neg p \vee q) \wedge p\) and that of \( (\neg p \wedge q) \vee p\)

p q \( \neg p \) \(\neg p \vee q\)

 \( (\neg p \vee q) \wedge p\) \( \neg p \wedge q\) \( (\neg p \wedge q) \vee p\)
True True
 {@taf@} {@tat@} {@tat@} {@taf@} {@tat@}
True
 False {@taf@} {@taf@} {@taf@} {@taf@} {@tat@}
False
 True
 {@tat@} {@tat@} {@taf@} {@tat@} {@tat@}
False
 False
 {@tat@} {@tat@} {@taf@} {@taf@} {@taf@}

2.(b). We notice in the second case that the truth tables are not the same. Therefore, the student's guess is false.

questionnote.text: How to fill in the truth tables for composed statements?

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
